owner().details: Returns the address of the current owner.

params.amounts: The amounts of each id to transfer
params.tokenId: 0 = rescue from this contract, non-zero = rescue from specified pool (cannot touch users' NFTs)

params.amount: The amount of tokens to send to the owner
params.tokenId: 0 = rescue from this contract, non-zero = rescue from specified pool
0 = rescue from this contract, non-zero = rescue from specified pool (cannot touch users' NFTs)

transferOwnership(address).details: Transfers ownership of the contract to a new account (`newOwner`). Disallows setting to the zero address as a way to more gas-efficiently avoid reinitialization When ownership is transferred, if the new owner implements IOwnershipTransferCallback, we make a callback Can only be called by the current owner.

_mapNFTIDToPool.details: mapping of token IDs to pools

_nextTokenId.details: The ID of the next token that will be minted. Skips 0

rescueERC1155(address,uint256[],uint256[.notice: Rescues ERC1155 tokens. Only callable by the owner if rescuing from this contract, else can be called by tokenId owner.There are some cases where an NFT is both ERC721 and ERC1155, so we have to ensure that the users' NFTs arent touched

rescueERC20(address,uint256,uint256).notice: Rescues ERC20 tokens. Only callable by the owner if rescuing from this contract, else can be called by tokenId owner.Since pools created cannot be paired with ERC20 tokens, there is no validation on the ERC20 token

rescueERC721(address,uint256[],uint256).notice: Rescues ERC721 tokens. Only callable by the owner if rescuing from this contract, else can be called by tokenId owner.
